title: 113_s115
content: The "Small Business Job Creation Act" includes a provision for an Employer Payroll Increase Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Small Business Job Creation Act" provides an Employer Payroll Increase Credit where qualified employers are treated as having made a payment against certain taxes for each qualified quarter. The credit amount is 10 percent of the qualified payroll increase, with a maximum limit of $500,000 for all qualified quarters. Qualified employers are defined as American employers excluding the United States, any State, or any instrumentality thereof. The term 'qualified payroll increase' refers to the amount by which a qualified employer's payroll for a quarter exceeds the previous year's same quarter. 'Qualified payroll' includes wages paid to employees, limited by the Social Security Act. Railway labor remuneration subject to tax is defined by substituting compensation for wages. A special rule applies to large employers with 100 or more employees, where a qualified payroll increase must exceed 3 percent of the previous year's payroll to be considered. A qualified quarter is defined as the calendar quarter including a specific date. The Small Business Job Creation Act defines a 'qualified quarter' as the calendar quarter including the enactment date and the following 3 quarters. The term 'employee' includes only US citizens or lawful residents receiving wages for work within the US. The Small Business Job Creation Act defines a 'qualified quarter' as the calendar quarter including the enactment date and the following 3 quarters. The section exempts qualified employers with fewer employees in a quarter compared to the previous quarter, excluding seasonal employees. Controlled groups of employers are treated as a single entity for dollar limitation purposes, except for non-American employers. New employers established after the enactment date are also covered under the Act. The Small Business Job Creation Act defines a 'qualified quarter' as the first calendar quarter of a qualified employer's existence and the following 3 quarters. The qualified payroll increase for the initial quarter is equal to the employer's qualified payroll for that quarter. The Small Business Job Creation Act defines a 'qualified quarter' as the first calendar quarter of a qualified employer's existence and the following 3 quarters. The qualified payroll increase for the initial quarter is the amount by which the employer's qualified payroll for that quarter exceeds the qualified payroll of the quarter preceding it. A transition rule applies to qualified employers that come into existence after a specific date but before the enactment of the Act. The qualified payroll increase for a transition quarter is the difference between the employer's qualified payroll for that quarter and the qualified payroll of the preceding quarter. The table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new item related to qualified payroll increase for a transition quarter. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue will notify employers about the new Employer payroll increase credits within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the Commissioner will provide quarterly reports to Congress on enforcement actions related to preventing fraud under section 6433 of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) shall apply to calendar quarters beginning with the calendar quarter which includes the date of the enactment of this Act.
